frontmatter.title: How to Calculate Standard Deviation
frontmatter.summary: Learn how to calculate standard deviation for both sample and population data, understand when to use each formula, and avoid common mistakes.

seo.metaDescription: Complete guide to calculating standard deviation with formulas, examples, and step-by-step instructions for sample and population data.

outcomes: Understand when to use each formula

steps.name: Organize Your Data
steps.description: List all your data points clearly. For example: 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20
steps.tip: Make sure your data is clean and doesn't contain any errors or outliers you don't want to include

steps.name: Calculate the Mean
steps.description: Add all values and divide by the count. Mean = (10 + 12 + 14 + 16 + 18 + 20) ÷ 6 = 90 ÷ 6 = 15
steps.tip: The mean is the center point from which we'll measure deviations

steps.name: Find Each Deviation
steps.warning: Keep the sign (positive or negative) for now - we'll square them next

steps.name: Square Each Deviation
steps.tip: Squaring removes negative signs and gives more weight to larger deviations

steps.name: Sum the Squared Deviations
steps.tip: This is called the sum of squares

steps.name: Divide by n or n-1
steps.description: For population: divide by n (6). For sample: divide by n-1 (5). Sample variance = 70 ÷ 5 = 14
steps.warning: Use n-1 for sample data (Bessel's correction) to avoid underestimating the population standard deviation

steps.name: Take the Square Root
steps.tip: The result is in the same units as your original data

steps.name: Interpret the Result
steps.description: A standard deviation of 3.74 means that on average, values deviate from the mean by about 3.74 units
steps.tip: About 68% of data falls within one standard deviation of the mean in a normal distribution

content: Standard deviation is a crucial measure of variability in statistics. It tells you how spread out your data is from the average (mean). This guide walks you through both sample and population standard deviation calculations, helping you understand when to use each and how to interpret the results.
